sp.p: And—What did he say to her?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Say?—He said, I don't know how many things to her.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay; but what?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, he said this and that, and t'other;—he said, he lov'd her mightily, and that she was the prettiest creature in the world.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well; and after that?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why, after that, he took her by the hand.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And after that?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: After that, he kiss'd her again.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And after that?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: After that.—Stay;—O! after that, my mamma came, and he ran away.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And you saw no more?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No; indeed, and indeed, papa.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: There's something, however, whispers in my ear that you have not told me all.—This little finger—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O that little finger's a story-teller.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Have a care.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Don't believe it, papa, it fibs indeed.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, get you gone then, and remember what I have said to you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, papa, yes, I'll remember.—I'm glad he didn't whip me; I was afraid he would have whip'd me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Come, now, brother, I must insist upon it, that you will not put yourself in a passion; but sit down here, and let me resume the conversation which we just now broke off.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well, come, let it be so.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You are to be cool now, remember.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I'll be cool.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And to answer me without prevarication.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Good Lord; yes, here's a terrible preamble sure.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How comes it then, brother, give me leave to ask you once more, that, being in the circumstances you are, and having no other children but two daughters, you can entertain the strange design of marrying your eldest in the manner you are going to dispose of her?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Pray, brother, how comes it that I am master of my own family, and dispose of my children as I like?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Your wife, no doubt, is glad to get rid of her at any rate.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Oh! ay, now it comes—and the poor wife is to be dragg'd in; 'tis she does all the mischief, to be sure, and all the world will have it so.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, no, brother, we'll leave her out of the question; she's a good woman, that has the best intentions in the world for your family, is free from all manner of self-interest, has a marvellous tenderness for you, and shews an inconceivable affection to your children, that's certain.—We'll say no more, therefore, of her, but return to your daughter; but, pray, let me ask you with what view wou'd you marry her to this Dr. Last?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: With a view of having so skillful a physician as Dr. Last related to me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Heav'ns! Brother, how can you talk so?—Skillful!—I never saw the man; but I'm told, that, of all the quacks in town, numerous as they are, he is the most ignorant, as well as the most impudent: but, it is really shocking to humanity, to consider to what a head these dangerous cheats are arriv'd in this great city; and, it is not less amazing, that people shou'd confide their health, their most valuable possession,
to wretches they wou'd not trust with any thing else: in short, I know no way of putting a stop to their progress, but by an unlimited act against the vending of poisons, which, I think, would very fairly comprehend them.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ha!—You have made a very fine speech now.—Do you think, if the cures they perform were not wonderful, people wou'd take their medicines so kindly?—What has essence of water-dock done for the scurvy?—What balsam of honey, in colds and consumptions?—The stomach pills for cholicky complaints?—Then, you senseless idiot you, d'ye think his majesty wou'd give his royal letters patent for pills, essences, electuaries, cordials, tinctures, quintessences, to poison his subjects?—But, to strike you dumb at once, is not that blessed medicine baume de vie, in itself, a remedy for all disorders under heaven?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: All.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Look at the list of cures—then the reasoning's good—All disorders spring from the stomach—Baume de vie is a sovereign remedy for the stomach—and therefore cures all disorders.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If so, why don't you take it, and get rid of yours?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why! why!—There's no general rule without an exception.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Come, come, brother, the truth of it is, there's nothing the matter with you at all; and I desire no better proof of the excellency of your constitution than, that all the slops you have been taking these ten years have not burst, or otherwise destroy'd you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Here's Dr. Last: he is so good as to come on purpose, to administer his medicine to me himself. Pray now, brother, behave yourself properly.

div2.head: SCENE IV.
div2.stage: AILWOU'D, FRIENDLY, and Dr. LAST, with a Vial in one Hand, and a Glass of Water in the other.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Ailwou'd—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Brother, with your leave.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What are you going to do now?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: To take some of Dr. Last's cordial; and, let me prevail upon you to take a glass too.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Do, Sir, one dose; it's as natural to a man's constitution as breast-milk; and, if you will take it for a continency, once you are a little manured to it, it will work the most surprisingest difference—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what is it?

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Sir, I wou'd not tell you if you were my father; no, nor king George; but I'll shew you—You see this glass of New River water—it's as transparent as rock crystial.—Now, I puts twelve drops of my cordial into it—and there—its as fine asses-milk as ever was tasted—I vow to the Lord, there's worse sold for a shilling a pint that comes from the beastis themselves.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well; I believe that's very true.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p:
I presume, by your wig, Sir, that you belong to the law; and, if you'll put yourself under my care, I'll give you something, for which you'll be oblig'd to me; and yet, its nothing
but the juice of a simple yerb; but I've tried it upon several gentlemen in your way, who, from being sheep, as it were, have become as bold as lions.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Attend to this, brother, for its worth listening to.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Then its one of the beautifullest things upon yearth for the memory—There was a little boy, seven years of age, did not know one of his letters—His papa was angry, his mamma was uneasy—They bought him the pretty books for children, letters in sweetmeats, gingerbread, ivory, all manner of play-things to make him take to his larning, but it wou'd not do: hearing of my secret, they apply'd to me; I gave the child a dose, and, will you believe it, upon the word of an honest man—he cou'd say his criss-cross-row in a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Now, that's very amazing! I'll make use of it myself, and begin to read immediately; for I never remember a word after the book is shut; and that's vexatious you know.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: And would you believe that this fine remedy was invented by my old mother?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Your mother!

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Why, she knows as much of physic as I do; its a gift in our family; and she has invented things to take spots out of cloaths, and iron-molds out of linen.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I long to be acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Well, will you swallow this now?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, come, give it to me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You jest, sure—Can't you be a moment without some nasty slop or another: put it off to a more convenient time, and give nature a little respite.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Well then, this evening, Dr. Last, or to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, may I be so bold as to ax if your name aint Groggins?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, Sir, my name's Friendly.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I desire to know, Sir, what business you have to hinder me in my occupation?—I say, the gentleman shall take it now, and I warrant it will do him good.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pr'ythee, man, what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: I means what I says.—Mr. Ailwou'd, will you take it?—If you don't take it, I'll go away directly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, do go away, Sir, we desire it.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: O! with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Brother, you'll be the cause of some mischief here.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What mischief?—No, no, brother, I shall be the cause of no mischief, but a great deal of good; and, I wish I cou'd drive away all the physic-mongers that come after you with their cursed drugs in the same manner, you'd live the longer for it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Some dreadful mischief will come of it, indeed—I must call him back—Dr. Last, Dr. Last.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Brother, for shame.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Don't talk to me, you want to send me to my grave—Dr. Last, pray come back.

sp.speaker: Last.
sp.p: (Fiercely to Friendly.] Did you call me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, doctor, but Mr. Ailwou'd did.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd, I'm not us'd politely here at all.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, it was not—

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: I have given that there thing to ladies; nay, to children that have been troubled with the worms, who never made a wry face, but lick'd their lips after it, as pleasantly, as if it had been so much treacle, or sugar-candy.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: It was not I—

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: And when I took the trouble of coming myself—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: 'Twas he—

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: In my own chariot—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: He was the cause—

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Without demanding nothing extraordinary for my trouble—I have a good mind not to marry your daughter—

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I tell you it was all my brother, it was, upon my word and credit—But, give me the cordial; and, to make you amends, I'll take double the quantity.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: No, he's not—I insist upon his taking it for the honour of my medicine—And if you don't take a glass too, you shall hear further from me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Very well, doctor, I fear your sword less than your poison.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: O, ay, poison, poison, we shall see whether it's poison.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Give it to me, doctor.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Here, Mr. Ailwou'd.

sp.speaker: Ail
sp.p: Pray now, brother, let me prevail upon you, in compliment to the doctor—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Nay, good brother, don't be absurd.

sp.speaker: D Last.
sp.p: Now, I'm satisfied; and, I'll call upon you again in an hour.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Get me my arm'd chair here—It's inconceivable what a warmth this med'cine diffuses all over my body.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, but brother, did not you hear Dr Last say just now that he was in doubt whether he wou'd marry your daughter or not; and, after so slighting an expression, surely, you will not persist in your design; but, let me talk to you of this gentleman who wishes to have my niece.

sp.speaker: Ail
sp.p: No, brother, if Dr. Last won't have her I'll send her to France, and put her in a convent; I'm sure she has an amorous inclination for somebody; and, to let you know, I have discover'd secret interviews in my house, which some people don't think I've discover'd.

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: I dare swear, brother, my niece has no attachment but to the gentleman I have mentioned to you; in which case, you have nothing to be angry with, all tending to the honourable purpose of marriage.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I don't care for what you say, I'll send her over to France, I'm determined on it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There's somebody you want to please, brother, by that, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I know your meaning, Sir; you're always harping upon the same strain.—My wife is a strange hobgoblin in your eyes, brother.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yes, brother, since 'tis necessary to be plain with you, 'tis your wife that I mean; and I can no more bear your ridiculous fondness for her, than that you have for physic; nor endure to see you run hand over-head into all the snares she lays for you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: O dear Sir, don't speak so of my lady; she's a woman that nobody can say any thing against; a woman without the least grain of artifice or design, and loves my master—There's no saying how much she loves him.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, only ask her how excessive fond she is of me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Most excessive!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: How much concern my illness gives her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And the care and pains she takes about me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: —Right.—Shall we convince you now, Mr. Friendly, and shew you directly what a surprising affection my lady has for my master?—Permit me, Sir, to undeceive him, and let him see his mistake.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: As how, Prudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Hark! my lady is just return'd—Do you step into the next room there—stretch yourself out, and feign yourself dead: he may slip into the closet: I'll set the doors open, and you'll see what violent grief she'll be in when I tell her the news.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Hey—hum!—I profess, I have a mind to take her advice—but, no; I can never bear to hear the shrieks and lamentations she'll make over me; and yet, 'twill be a comfort to me to hear them too, to feel her virtuous tears bedew my face, and her sweet lips kissing my cheeks a thousand times, to bring me back again to life: and her—ah, verily, I'll do it; verily, I'll do it; and then, Sir, what will become of your fine surmises?—But, Prudence, art thou not afraid that her very thinking me dead will break her heart?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: To be sure, Sir, if you shou'd keep her in her fright too long.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: O, let me alone for that; I'll make the experiment this very minute; this very minute.—But is there no danger in feigning one's self dead?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No, no; what danger shou'd there be? 'Tis only shutting your eyes, and stretching yourself out. [To Friendly.] Now, Sir, we shall shew you your error, and convince yow how much you have injur'd the best of wives. [To Ailwou'd.] 'Twill be pleasant enough afterwards, to see how blank he will look—Here's my lady; quick, quick, both of you away.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh! Heav'ns! Oh! fatal misfortune! what a strange accident is this!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: What's the matter, Prudence!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Crying.] Ah! madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: What is it? What do you mean by blubbering, pr'ythee?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: My master's dead, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Dead!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Sobbing.] Ye-ye-yes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Too sure, alas! No body yet knows any thing of this accident: there was not a soul but myself to help him; he sunk down in my arms, and went off like a child—See there, madam, he lies stretch'd out in the next room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Now, Heav'n be prais'd.—What a simpleton art thou to cry?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Cry, ma'am; why, I thought we were to cry?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: And for what, pray?—I know of no loss he is—Was he of any use upon earth?—A man troublesome to all the world; odious in his person; disgusting in his manners; never without some filthy medicine in his mouth, or his stomach; continually coughing, hawking, and spitting; a tiresome, peevish, disagreeable monster.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: An excellent funeral sermon, truly. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Prudence, you must assist me in the execution of my design; and you may depend upon it, I will amply reward your services: since, by good fortune, no one is yet appris'd of this accident besides ourselves, let us keep his death a secret a few days, till I have been able to settle my affairs on a sure foundation: there are papers and money, of which I wou'd possess myself—Nor, indeed, is it just, that all I have suffer'd with him living, shou'd not be rewarded by some advantage at his death.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: To be sure, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: In the mean time, I'll go and secure his keys, for I know he has a considerable sum of money in his scrutore, which he receiv'd yesterday.

div2.head: SCENE IX.
div2.stage: AILWOU'D, FRIENDLY, PRUDENCE, and Mrs. AILWOU'D, who, going to the Door, meets her husband, and screams.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Ah! ah! ah!— [Screaming.]

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: O! devil of a help-mate, have I found you out?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Your servant, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Lord! my dear, I'm so disappointed—so pleas'd, I mean, and so frighten'd—This wicked girl told me you were dead.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Yes, and a fine oration you pronounc'd over me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Nay, but my dear, this is the most unreasonable thing; [Turning to Friendly.] some slight conversation that I have had with my maid here, which Mr. Ailwou'd takes in a wrong sense; but, I dare swear, when he has consider'd the matter a little, he will think differently.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Get out of my sight, get out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Well, but lovey, let me explain the matter to you.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I'll never hear a word from you again as as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Ail.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if you bear yourself so haughtily, you'll find me a match for you. It is not to-day, my dear I am to learn, that your brain is full of maggots; however, you shall call me more than once, before I come back to you, I assure you.

div2.head: SCENE X.
div2.stage: AILWOU'D, FRIENDLY, PRUDENCE; and then NANCY and HARGRAVE.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Did you ever hear such an impudent creature?—Od's my life, with what an air she carried it!—But do'st think she was in earnest, Prudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Troth do I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Come, brother, to tell you the plain truth, Prudence devis'd this method, in order to open your eyes to your wife's perfidy—She has long deceiv'd you with a shew of false tenderness; but now, you see her in her genuine colours.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I profess my eyes are dazzled, and all my senses confus'd; I know not what I either hear or see; but, in the first place, I renounce physic—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Lord! Sir, here's Miss Nancy and Mr. Hargrave!

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear papa, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: The matter, child! I don't know, child. (Seeing Hargrave.) What brings you here, Sir?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This, brother, is the young gentleman I propose as a match for your daughter; and after what I have said, and what has happen'd, I hope, you will no longer refuse to listen to his prentions.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, really, Sir, my chief objection to you, is your total ignorance of the medicinal art; if you can think of any method to remove that—

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I must own, Sir, I'm afraid I am rather too far advanc'd in life to make any progress in so deep and abstracted a study.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Why, with regard to the more capital branches, I grant you; but in the subaltern offices, I'm of a contrary opinion; suppose now you were to bind yourself apprentice for a year or two to some skilful apothecary; surely, in that time you might learn to decypher a prescription, and make up a medicine with very few blunders.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: D'ye think so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: You might, indeed, now and then give a dose of arsenick for salts; but that's an accident might happen to the oldest practitioner.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ah, brother, brother, what's this I hear! It was but this moment you were determin'd to renounce physic, and here you are talking as warmly and absurdly about it as ever.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Eh!—It's very true, indeed, brother.—However, let it suffice, I give the young man my daughter without any conditions at all; and now, I'll go and get effectually rid of that other plague my wife; for I shall not be easy while we areunder the same roof.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If we can't cure him of his love for drugs, we have done nothing.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I doubt, Sir, that will be impossible.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Hist, here comes Dr. Last—I'll take the opportunity of your father's absence to have
some sport with him; put on melancholly countenances, and take your cues from me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I know what you'd be at, Sir, and I'll second you.

div2.head: SCENE XII.
div2.stage: FRIENDLY, HARGRAVE, PRUDENCE, NANCY, Dr. LAST, and afterwards AILWOU'D.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Mr. Ailwou'd, where are you? I have brought you some of my essence of cucumber, by way of a taste.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O, Dr. Last, you're come; you're servant Sir, I'm glad to see you.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Sir, I'm oblyg'd to you—Where is Mr. Ailwou'd?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Where is he, Sir?—

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Ay; because I wants to speak to him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: He's dead, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [Bursting ridiculously into tears.] Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: What's the matter, Mrs. Prudence? I warrant your master is only in a sound, and I've a bottle of stuff in my pocket that will fetch him in a whiff.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, no more of your stuff.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Well then, let me go and feel his pulse.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Nor that neither; you shan't go near him; but, we insist upon your telling us what you gave him out of your vial just now?

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: How! tell you my secret—A bookseller offer'd me a thousand pounds for it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p:
A bookseller offer'd you a thousand pound! That may be, Sir, but Mr. Ailwou'd
died a few minutes after you administer'd it; we, therefore, take it for granted, that it has poison'd him; and, unless you prove very clearly to the contrary, we shall consider you as his murderer, and treat you accordingly.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: O, don't think to humbug me so.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: [Enters behind.] What are they doing here?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Dear Sir, have patience—Stop where you are a little, and let them go on.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Within there; seize this fellow.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Liberty—I'm a free-born Briton, in my native city—If any one lays a finger upon me, I'll put him into the Crown-office.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ay, but we'll put you in Newgate first—Carry him before a justice, I'll go and be witness.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ay, and so will I.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: (In a great passion.) Well, but stay; let me go a-bit—What will you be witness of?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: That you poison'd my master.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: It can't be.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: We'll prove it.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: It's a fictious report; for to let you see the difference now—what I gave him was nothing in the world but a little chalk and vinegar; and if it cou'd do him no good, it cou'd do him no harm.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: And so, sirrah, this is the way you take people in; your famous cordial then is, chalk and vinegar?

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: What! Mr. Ailwou'd, aren't you dead?

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p:
No, sirrah; but no thanks to you for that; so get you out of my house, or I'll chalk
and vinegar you with a vengeance, you pretending, quacking, cheating—

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Don't strike me.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I'll break every bone in your skin if you don't get out of my house.

sp.speaker: Friend,
sp.p: Nay, brother—

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: My own chariot's below.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A cart, a wheelbarrow, for such scoundrels.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: Don't call me out of my name.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: I can't, sirrah.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: You did, you did, and I'll make you pay for it.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Get out of my house.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: That's all I want—He has push'd me—I call you every one to witness—I'll swear to the assault—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Take him away.

sp.speaker: D. Last.
sp.p: (As they are taking him away.) I'll swear to the assault—and, if I don't get redemnification—

div2.head: SCENE LAST.
div2.stage: AILWOU'D, FRIENDLY, HARGRAVE, NANCY, PRUDENCE, POLLY.

sp.speaker: Polly.
sp.p: Papa! papa!

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: What's the matter, my dear?

sp.speaker: Polly.
sp.p: My mamma's gone abroad, and says she'll never come home no more; so she won't.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: A good riddance; a good riddance.

sp.speaker: Polly.
sp.p: Lau, papa! if that isn't the man I saw just now kissing my sister.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ah! you little tell-tale.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed, Prudence, but I'm no tell-tale, so I an't; for he kiss'd me too, and I never said a word of it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, my dear, he's to be marry'd to your sister now.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Is he?—And won't you get somebody to marry me, papa? You've been promising me a husband a great while, and I'm tired of old John the butler.

sp.speaker: Ail.
sp.p: Ay, my dear, I dare swear you'll lose no time—But, come, brother, let us now go in.—I have got rid of my wife; I have forsworn quacks and physic—and, I hope, I shall have the satisfaction to see our friends contented.

div1.head: EPILOGUE.
div1.byline: Spoken by a LITTLE GIRL of Five Years old.

lg.l: LADIES and gentlemen, they've sent me out—
But I'm afraid to tell you what about;
Because 'twere bold in me, perhaps you'll say,
To come to ask you how you like the play:
Yet that's my business; nay, more free to make,
I'm come to beg you'd like it for my sake.
The author took me in his arms just now,
My dear, says he—he kiss'd me too I vow—
If you'll go out and make the audience clap,
I'll give you ribbons and a fine new cap:
Besides, he promis'd me, next time he comes
Behind the scenes, to bring me sugar-plumbs.
But whatsoe'er you think the play to be,
When you go home I'm sure you'll talk of me.
Says Lady Stingo to Sir Gilbert mild,
"At FOOTE's, Sir Gilbert, have you seen the child!
"'Tis really a curosity to view her:
"Our little Betsy is a mountain to her!
"Such action, such a tongue—and yet I query
"If she be five years old—a very fairy!"
Sir Gilbert answers, with a pevish nod,
"P'shaw! let the little hussy have a rod.
"There are old folks enough to play the fool:
"Children, my lady, shou'd be sent to school."
And so they should, the naughty ones, no doubt,
Who'll neither books nor needle learn without:
But I am come of no such idle breed;
At four years old, I could both write and read;
To be at work my fingers still are itching—
These flowers here are all of my own stitching.
But, is my prate disliked, for after all,
I am but young, 'tis true, and somewhat small;
And taller ladies, I must needs confess,
Might speak an epilogue with more address.
However, some few things I have to plead:
First, 'pon my word and credit, I'm a maid.
Will that pass here for merit?—I don't know—
I'm a new face—which generally does so.
And if you want me louder, taller, bolder,
Have patience—I shall mend, as I grow older.
